0968987 Colorado State University; W. S. Sampath

NGPV is seeking a Phase I support (first five years) for the Center, including support for center personnel, evaluation and research. The proposed Center is a single-university Center led by the Colorado State University (CSU).

The proposed Center will develop with industry partners, new materials, precursors, and formulations for manufacturing high performance and low-cost NGPVs that have great potential for energy sustainability. Novel materials, processing strategies, and device structures that result from fundamental materials discovery research at CSU will then be evaluated and optimized with a focus on thin film CdTe PVs. The aim of the proposed research is to overcome the scientific challenges outlined in the National CdTe Roadmap.

A solution to deceasing PV manufacturing costs significantly would mean widespread adoption of solar cell technology worldwide and a decrease in the worlds reliance on non-renewable energy resources. The proposed deliverables and outcome of this proposal include: fundamental understanding and
advancement of PV devices, hands-on experience for students to learn PV technology, and advancing the technology by demonstrating improvement in device performance, and meeting the goals of the National CdTe roadmap. The Center plans to interface with some key educational programs (such as the green technology focus), and to have a team of faculty and students that is diverse in gender, race and ethnicity.

I/UCRC for Next Generation Photovoltaics

Project Outcomes

 

This NSF program supports the Colorado State University (CSU) site of Industry/University Co-Operative Research Center for Next Generation Photovoltaics (PV). The site is referred to as "IUCRC" in this report. The focus of the research at CSU is CdTe thin film Photovoltaics. The major goal of the IUCRC is to "make PV electricity a major source of energy". 

Electricity generation by CdTe thin-film photovoltaics (PV) offers a strong potential to substantially increase renewable energy and lead to sustainable generation of electricity. CdTe PV is currently competitive for generating electricity in many parts of the world (e.g. 7-9 cents/kWh from utility scale projects without subsidy) and the costs are decreasing rapidly. Recently, an agreement was made to sell CdTe-generated electricity from a new 100-MW utility scale installation at 3.87 cents/kWh. The IUCRC has contributed to lowering the cost of electricity from CdTe PV. The cost of electricity from CdTe PV is lower than the average price of electricity in the US, which is 10 cents/kWh. An example of a utility scale installation is shown in Figure 1. This installation was built by First Solar, an active member of the IUCRC. First Solar has installed 10 GWs of CdTe PV and it is estimated that additional 3 GWs will be installed in 2016.

Intellectual Merit:

The IUCRC has developed advanced research infrastructure for enhancing CdTe thin film PV devices. With this infrastructure, the efficiency of CdTe PV device was increased from 10.6% to 18.3% on low cost sodalime glass with process suitable for mass production. These are world-class efficiencies on these substrates. It is estimated that the efficiencies would be ~20% on more transparent glass substrates. The work completed under phase I has led to the development of the roadmap for the future as shown in Figure 2. In addition to the significant increase in device efficiencies, a detailed understanding of many aspects of CdTe PV has been developed. These include: effect of the CdCl2 passivation treatment on the grain boundaries and stacking faults at atomic resolution, electronic band alignment by UV photoelectron spectroscopy, polycrystalline epitaxial growth of CdMgTe on CdTe and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) of hundreds of films and devices.

In addition to the advances in understanding and increase in efficiency of the devices, many industrial technologies have been developed. Some of the technologies have been commercialized (pl. see below) and have been implemented in the industry. All the results have been broadly disseminated in invited talks, publications, etc.

Broader Impacts:

At the CSU site, 10 graduate students have been "student leads" for I/UCRC sponsored projects. The IUCRC and the infrastructure developed in the IUCRC have contributed to the graduate education of 8 Ph. D students (5 have graduated) and 7 MS students (all graduated).  The close relationship of the students with the IAB and the focus of solving real world, industrial problems has led to all of the students who have worked on the projects either have moved to pursue their Ph.D or have been hired by industry within 6 months of graduating.  In a few cases, students were hired into IAB member companies.  In addition to graduate students, since 2010, 14 veteran and undergraduate students have been formally supported and mentored at the CSU site.
